item.title: iBuild Triumphs at The Northern Business Achievement Awards
item.dc:creator: admin
item.ns2:encoded:
IBUILD CROWNED BUSINESS OF THE YEAR AT NBAA 2022

With an innovative manufacturing approach that has created hundreds of flat-packed homes, iBuild has triumphed at this year's Northern Business Achievement Awards (NBAA), earning the NBAA Business of the Year 2022, Export Award 2022, and Technology Award 2022. The NBAA are a partnership of industry, education, local and state government, and decision-makers across Melbourne's north. They recognise the achievements of small businesses and encourage business excellence, growth, and competitiveness. The awards recognised how iBuild helps Australian families to take control of their housing destiny with their own two hands instead of relying on a traditional and potentially unreliable builder. Michael Zeng, iBuild's Operations Director, commented on iBuild's win, stating, "I'm very proud and humbled by the Northern Business Achievement Awards recognition of iBuild's development of growing from nothing to helping over 100 hundred Australians build their own home every year."
iBuild's goal is to help Australians become homeowners by providing housing solutions that can put more families in more homes with less time and less cost. Michael Zeng, iBuild Operations Director
Michael, on the significance of the awards, said, "The Northern Business Achievements Awards acknowledgment of iBuild highlights just how crucial local manufacturing is for Australia. We at iBuild are happy that our work to make Australia a world leader in manufacturing is being recognised by the broader Australian community."

NBAA AWARDS

IBUILD NBAA HIGHLIGHTS

  •  iBuild has won:
  • NBAA Business of The Year 2022 (Sponsored By Vic Government) 
  • NBAA Export Award 2022 (Sponsored by Pitch Partners) 
  • NBAA Technology Award 2022 (Sponsored by Business NBN) 
  • iBuild manufactures more than 100 flatpack kit homes every year 
  • iBuild Has gone from zero to a local manufacturer hero 
  • The Hume City Council nominated iBuild for the NBAA following iBuild's success in winning the Hume Business of the Year Award 2021. 

You May Also Be Interested In

item.title: Owner Builder Victoria
item.dc:creator: admin
item.ns2:encoded:
HOW TO BECOME AN OWNER BUILDER IN VICTORIA

1. UNDERSTAND OWNER BUILDER RESPONSIBILITIES

As an owner-builder in Victoria, you will have certain responsibilities under the VBA regulations. These responsibilities include obtaining necessary permits, complying with building codes and regulations, ensuring the work is carried out by qualified tradespeople, managing the construction process, and organizing inspections.

CLICK ON THE IMAGE BELOW TO LEARN MORE ABOUT OWNER BUILDING IN VICTORIA

2. OBTAIN NECESSARY PERMITS

Before you start any construction work, you will need to obtain the necessary permits from your local council. This includes a building permit, which is issued by the relevant building surveyor, and any other permits required for specific work such as plumbing, electrical, or gas fitting. 

CLICK THE IMAGE BELOW TO LEARN MORE ABOUT VICTORIAN WHITE CARDS

3. COMPLY WITH BUILDING CODES AND REGULATIONS

As an owner-builder, you are responsible for ensuring that all construction work complies with the relevant building codes and regulations in Victoria. This includes the Building Code of Australia (BCA), which sets out the minimum requirements for the design and construction of buildings, and any local council requirements.

CLICK THE IMAGE BELOW TO DOWNLOAD THE VBA'S OWNER BUILDER INFORMATION AND STUDY GUIDE

4. ENGAGE QUALIFIED TRADESPEOPLE

Under the VBA regulations, you are required to engage qualified tradespeople to carry out certain types of work, such as plumbing, electrical, and gas fitting.  It is important to verify the qualifications and registration status of any tradespeople you engage for your project.

5. MANAGE THE CONSTRUCTION PROCESS

As an owner-builder, you are responsible for managing the entire construction process, including coordinating tradespeople, ordering materials, and overseeing the quality of work. This includes regular site inspections to ensure that the work is being carried out to the required standard.

6. ORGANISE INSPECTIONS

You will need to arrange inspections at various stages of the construction process to ensure that the work complies with the building permit and relevant regulations. This includes inspections for footings, framing, plumbing, electrical, and final inspections. Inspections must be carried out by a registered building surveyor, and any defects identified during inspections must be rectified before proceeding to the next stage.

7. KEEP RECORDS

As an owner-builder, you are required to keep accurate records of all the work carried out on your construction project, including contracts, invoices, receipts, permits, and inspection reports. These records may be required for future reference, such as when selling your property.

CLICK BELOW TO DOWNLOAD THE OWNER BUILDER VICTORIA CHECKLIST

8. OBTAIN INSURANCE

If you are planning to sell your owner-built home within 6 years and 6 months of obtaining the occupancy permit, you will need to obtain domestic building insurance, also known as home warranty insurance. This insurance provides coverage to subsequent owners in case of defects in the construction work.

9. FOLLOW SAFETY REGULATIONS

As an owner-builder, you are responsible for ensuring that the construction site is safe for workers, visitors, and the public. This includes complying with occupational health and safety regulations, providing appropriate safety equipment, and taking necessary precautions to prevent accidents and injuries.

These responsibilities include obtaining necessary permits, complying with building codes and regulations, ensuring the work is carried out by qualified tradespeople, managing the construction process, and organizing inspections.

item.title: Owner Builder QLD
item.dc:creator: admin
item.ns2:encoded:
How to Become an Owner Builder in Queensland

If you're planning to build a home in Queensland, iBuild can help you become an owner builder with ease. Our Owner Builder step-by-step guide for Queensland provides essential information on being an owner builder, including explaining the role of the Queensland Building and Construction Commission (QBCC). With this comprehensive guide and an iBuild kit home, you will have all the resources you need to become an owner builder in Queensland.

1. Check if you are eligible to be an owner builder

In Queensland, you must meet certain requirements to be eligible for an owner builder permit. You must be an individual, not a company, and the property must be your primary place of residence or intended to be your primary place of residence after completion. You also need to complete a mandatory owner builder course and pass an assessment before applying for a permit.

2. Apply for an owner builder permit

Once you have completed the owner builder course and assessment, you can apply for an owner builder permit from QBCC. The permit will allow you to undertake building or renovation work on your property as an owner builder. You need to provide QBCC with detailed plans, specifications, and a list of proposed subcontractors, as well as evidence of your eligibility to be an owner builder.

3. Obtain relevant approvals

Before commencing any work, you need to obtain relevant approvals from local council, such as a building approval or development approval, as well as any other approvals required by law. You also need to ensure that your project complies with relevant building codes and standards.

4. Arrange Appropriate insurances

This includes obtaining public liability insurance and construction works insurance to protect yourself, your property, and any visitors or workers from any potential accidents or damages that may occur during the building process. It is important to ensure that your insurance coverage meets the requirements of your owner builder permit and any legal obligations.

5. Manage the building process

As an owner builder, you will be responsible for managing the building process, including sourcing and supervising subcontractors, ordering materials, and ensuring that the work is completed to a high standard. You also need to comply with relevant health and safety regulations and ensure that your worksite is safe for workers and visitors.

6. Complete the project

Once your building project is completed, you need to obtain a final inspection and certification from a building certifier to confirm that the work complies with relevant building codes and standards. You also need to ensure that any subcontractors are paid and that any outstanding debts are settled.

Click on the image below to download the QBCC Owner builder study guide

*Please note that this study guide is outdated and some of the information within the document may be obsolete. However, it still provides valuable advice for owner builders in QLD.

item.title: Owner Builder WA
item.dc:creator: admin
item.ns2:encoded:
If you're planning on building your dream home in Western Australia then becoming an owner builder with iBuild is the way to go. Our step-by-step guide will assist you through every step of the process. Whether you're a seasoned builder or completely new to the process, our comprehensive guide offers essential information about owner building in WA.

1.Licensing and Permit Requirements

a. Before commencing any owner builder work, you must obtain an owner builder approval from DMIRS. This ensures that you meet the necessary criteria and are aware of your obligations. b. An owner builder approval is required for any construction work with a value exceeding $20,000 (including labor and materials). c. For any electrical, plumbing, and gas fitting work, licensed professionals must be engaged to perform the tasks. d. It is essential to check if your property has any planning restrictions or special conditions that may affect your building project.

2.Planning and Building Approvals

a. Consult your local council or shire to determine if you need development approval or a building permit before starting your project. b. Submit the required documentation, including detailed plans, specifications, and engineering details, to the local council or a private building surveyor for assessment and approval. c. Building permits must be obtained before commencing any construction work.

3.Insurance and Indemnity

a. As an owner builder, you are responsible for obtaining the appropriate insurance coverage for your project. This may include construction works insurance, public liability insurance, and home indemnity insurance. b. Home indemnity insurance is mandatory for owner builders selling their property within seven years of completing the project.

4. Workplace Safety

a. As the owner builder, you have the primary duty of care for the health and safety of all workers and visitors to the construction site. b. Familiarize yourself with the Occupational Safety and Health Act and Regulations to ensure compliance with safety requirements. c. Implement appropriate safety measures, including providing suitable personal protective equipment, ensuring safe access and egress, and maintaining a hazard-free work environment. d. Consult the DMIRS and Safe Work Australia websites for comprehensive information on workplace safety requirements.

5.Completion and Certification

a. When construction is complete, engage a registered building surveyor to inspect and certify that the work complies with relevant regulations and standards. b. Obtain a Certificate of Building Compliance (CBC) or a Certificate of Construction Compliance (CCC) from the building surveyor, as required by your local council. c. Keep all relevant documentation, including warranties, certificates, and compliance documents, as they may be required for future purposes, such as property sales.

item.dc:creator: admin
item.ns2:encoded:
If you're planning to build a home in Tasmania, iBuild can help you become an owner builder with ease. Our Owner Builder step-by-step guide for Tasmania provides essential information on being an owner builder in Tasmania, including the role of Tasmania Government. With this comprehensive guide and an iBuild kit home, you will have all the resources you need to become an owner builder in Tasmania.

1. Understand Owner Builder Requirements

  • Ensure you meet the eligibility criteria for becoming an owner builder in Tasmania.
  • Obtain necessary planning permits or approvals from the local council or planning authority.

2. Plan and Design

  • Engage professionals like architects or draftspersons for assistance.
  • Prepare detailed building plans and specifications.

3. Apply for Permits

  • Obtain a building permit from the local council or building surveyor.
  • Check if additional permits (e.g., plumbing or electrical) are required.

4. Construction

  • Hire licensed tradespeople or contractors.
  • Oversee construction to ensure compliance with approved plans and regulations.
  • Implement safety measures on the construction site.

5. Completion and Inspections

  • Apply for a completion certificate once construction is finished.
  • Schedule final inspections by relevant authorities.

6. Occupancy and Beyond

  • Obtain an occupancy permit to legally occupy the completed dwelling.
  • Take responsibility for ongoing maintenance and warranty of the building.

item.title: Owner Builder NT
item.dc:creator: admin
item.ns2:encoded:
How to Become an Owner builder in NT

If you're planning to build a home in NT, iBuild can help you become an owner builder with ease. Our Owner Builder step-by-step guide for NT provides essential information on being an owner builder in NT, including the role of NT Government. With this comprehensive guide and an iBuild kit home, you will have all the resources you need to become an owner builder in NT.

1. Understand the Role of an Owner Builder

Before embarking on your owner builder journey, it's crucial to understand the responsibilities and obligations that come with the role. As an owner builder, you will be in charge of supervising or undertaking the construction or renovation work on your own property. This involves planning, organizing, and coordinating various aspects of the project, including obtaining necessary permits and ensuring compliance with building regulations.

2.Determine Your Eligibility

In the Northern Territory, you must meet certain eligibility criteria to become an owner builder. These criteria may include being the owner of the land or having a legal interest in the land, ensuring the work is for your own residential use, and being able to demonstrate the necessary skills and knowledge to manage the project effectively.

3. Obtain an Owner Builder Certificate

To become an owner builder in the Northern Territory, you must obtain an Owner Builder Certificate. This certificate demonstrates that you have met the eligibility requirements and have the necessary knowledge to undertake the project. The certificate is issued by the Building Practitioners Board. To apply for the Owner Builder Certificate, you will need to:
  1. Complete the application form: Download the application form from the Northern Territory government website or obtain a physical copy from a Territory Business Centre.
  2. Provide supporting documentation: Attach the required documents, including proof of ownership or legal interest in the land, evidence of your residential use, and any qualifications or experience that demonstrate your competence in managing the project.
  3. Pay the application fee: Submit the application form along with the applicable fee, which can be found on the government website or by contacting the Building Practitioners Board.
  4. Await assessment: The Building Practitioners Board will assess your application and notify you of the outcome. If approved, you will receive your Owner Builder Certificate.

4. Understand Your Responsibilities

As an owner builder, you are responsible for complying with all relevant building codes, regulations, and requirements. Some key responsibilities include:
  1. Obtaining necessary permits: Before commencing any construction or renovation work, you must obtain the required permits from the Northern Territory government authorities. This may include building permits, development permits, and plumbing permits, among others.
  2. Supervising the project: You must actively supervise the work being carried out, ensuring it meets the required standards and adheres to the approved plans and specifications.
  3. Engaging licensed tradespeople: Certain aspects of the project, such as electrical and plumbing work, must be carried out by licensed tradespeople. It's important to engage qualified professionals for these specialized tasks.
  4. Meeting insurance requirements: As an owner builder, you may be required to obtain specific insurance coverage, such as construction and public liability insurance, to protect yourself and others involved in the project.
  5. Maintaining records: Keep detailed records of all transactions, contracts, and inspections related to the project. These records will be valuable for future reference and may be required if you decide to sell your property.

5. Seek Professional Advice

While taking on the role of an owner builder allows you to have greater control over your project, it's advisable to seek professional advice. The iBuild team offers such assistance, with a dedicated project manager accompanying you throughout every stage of your project's journey. To learn more , click on the following link: Click Here

6. Completion and Certification

Once your construction or renovation work is complete, you must arrange for the final inspections and certifications required by the Northern Territory government. These inspections will typically cover various aspects of the project, including structural integrity, plumbing, and electrical installations. Upon successful completion of the inspections, you will receive the necessary certifications, allowing you to occupy or sell your property.

item.title: Owner Builder SA
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.ns2:encoded:
How to Become an Owner builder in South Australia

If you're planning to build a home in South Australia, iBuild can help you become an owner builder with ease. Our Owner Builder step-by-step guide for South Australia provides essential information on being an owner builder in South Australia, including the role of South Australian Government. With this comprehensive guide and an iBuild kit home, you will have all the resources you need to become an owner builder in South Australia.

1. Development Approval Process

  • Contact your local council: Reach out to your local council to understand their specific requirements and procedures for obtaining Development Approval.
  • Submit the application: Prepare and submit the Development Approval application, including all required documentation and plans as per the council's guidelines.
  • Assessment and decision: The council will assess your application against the Development Plan and Building Rules. They may request additional information if needed. Once assessed, they will provide a decision on your application.

Click on the image Below To Go To Plan SA Website

2. Construction Industry Training Levy

  • Payment requirement: If the estimated value of your building works exceeds $15,000, you must pay the Construction Industry Training Levy. The levy amounts to 0.25% of the value of the building works.
  • Before Building Rules Consent: Ensure that the levy is paid before the council issues the Building Rules Consent.

Click on the image Below To learn More about getting your White Card in South Australia

3. Commencement and Completion

  • Start building work: As an owner builder, you have 12 months from the date of Development Approval to commence the building work.
  • Completion timeline: The construction must be completed within three years from the date of Development Approval. If needed, you can apply for an extension under specific circumstances.

Click on the image Below on to see South Australia's building consumer guide

4. Changes during Construction

  • Material or method changes: If you decide to alter any material or method of construction during the building phase, you must contact the relevant authority.
  • Pre-approval for major changes: Major changes that affect the structural soundness or safety of the building must be pre-approved by the relevant authority.

Click on the image Below on to see South Australia Owner Builder Fact Sheet

5. Inspections

  • Building work supervisor or private certifier: Engage a registered building work supervisor or private certifier to oversee the construction from start to finish and sign a Statement of Compliance.
  • Statement of Compliance: The Statement of Compliance consists of two parts. Part A, the Builders Statement, certifies that the building work is completed according to approved documentation. Part B, the Owners Statement, must be signed by the landowner.
  • Random inspections: The council may conduct random inspections at various stages of the building process.

6. Owner Builder Responsibilities

  • Trade qualifications and courses: Owner builders do not require formal trade qualifications or specific courses.
  • Number of projects: There is no limit on the number of owner builder projects you can undertake. However, if you organize the construction or renovation of two or more buildings within a five-year period, you may be considered a building work contractor.
  • Licensed professionals: Certain specialist work, such as plumbing, gas fitting, and electrical work, must be carried out by licensed professionals.
  • Legislative requirements: Owner builders are responsible for meeting the same legislative requirements as licensed builders. You are accountable for the safety of all individuals on the construction site, as well as the actions of contracted workers or visitors.

Click on the image Below on to see South Australia's Owner Builder Responsibilities guide

7. Notifications

  • Notifications to the council: Provide one business day's notice to the council when commencing building work, completing the building work, and for any other stages of work specified in the Development Approval.
  • Excavation and fill requirements: If excavating 600mm or more near a property boundary or placing 200mm or more of fill near the boundary, you must notify the owners of adjoining property in writing at least 28 days before commencing. Additionally, comply with any conditions imposed by the relevant authority.

8. Insurance

  • Contract and insurance requirements: The Building Work Contractors Act 1995 mandates that owner builders have signed contracts with suppliers for all domestic building work costing $12,000 or more.
  • Building Indemnity Insurance: Owner builders cannot obtain Building Indemnity Insurance themselves. However, licensed building work contractors must have this insurance for building work contracts costing $12,000 or more that require council consent. They must supply the owner builder with a certificate of indemnity insurance.
  • Other recommended insurances: It is advisable to have Public Liability Insurance, Construction Insurance, and Householder Insurance in place during the building process.
  • Please be aware that although this document is outdated, it may still contain some useful information. However, it is crucial that you consult the appropriate authorities, such as your local council or Plan SA, to confirm your responsibilities as an owner-builder.

You May Also Be Interested In

*The information provided on this webpage is for general information purposes only and should not be considered as professional advice.

Our Owner Builder step-by-step guide for South Australia provides essential information on being an owner builder in South Australia, including the role of South Australian Government. With this comprehensive guide and an iBuild kit home, you will have all the resources you need to become an owner builder in South Australia.

item.title: 2023 Monash Business School Awards
item.dc:creator: Roger
item.ns2:encoded:
At iBuild, we firmly believe in recognising and nurturing exceptional talent. That's why we were thrilled to sponsor along with some of Australia's biggest names last month's Monash Business Schools 2023 Deans Excellence Awards, where iBuild's Project Engineer, Hosea Ivan Christofer, presented the international business student excellence award to the night's only double winner Anouschka Freyny. iBuild sponsored the awards along with some of Australia's biggest names. Through our partnerships with higher education institutions like Monash University, iBuild has played a crucial role in empowering hundreds of interns, enabling them to gain invaluable industry experience and cultivate essential skills. We firmly believe in investing in the future, which is why a significant number of our new employees are recruited from our pool of past interns.

2023 Monash Business School Awards Highlight

  • iBuild presented the international business student excellence award at the Monash Business Schools 2023 Deans Excellence Awards.
  • iBuild has had a longstanding collaboration with Monash Business School and other top 8 Universities.

item.title: Owner Builder ACT
item.dc:creator: ITSupport
item.ns2:encoded:
How to Become an Owner Builder ACT

If you're planning to build a home in ACT, iBuild can help you become an owner builder with ease. Our Owner Builder step-by-step guide for ACT provides essential information on being an owner builder in ACT, including the role of the ACT Government. With this comprehensive guide and an iBuild kit home, you will have all the resources you need to become an owner builder in ACT.

1. Check eligibility

Ensure you meet the eligibility criteria to be an owner builder in the ACT. Typically, owner builders must intend to build or renovate a residential dwelling for personal use and must not intend to sell or rent the property within one year of completion.

2.Prepare a construction plan

Engage an architect, draftsperson, or building designer to help you prepare a detailed construction plan. Ensure the project meets all building codes and regulations. It should include architectural drawings, engineering details, and any other required documentation.

3. Obtain necessary permits

Contact your local council and the ACT Planning and Land Authority (ACTPLA) to obtain the permits needed for your building project. These may include development approvals, building approvals, and any other permits required. Ensure compliance with planning and building regulations.

4. Apply for an owner builder license

Apply for an owner builder license to Access Canberra. Provide required documentation, including your construction plan, insurance certificates, and evidence of eligibility. Pay applicable fees.

5. Insurance

Obtain owner builder construction insurance and public liability insurance to protect against risks and liabilities during construction. Ensure you have appropriate coverage for your project.

6. Engage professionals

If needed, engage qualified professionals such as structural engineers, surveyors, and energy efficiency assessors to assess and certify various aspects of your project.

7.Construction and supervision

Undertake or supervise the construction work according to approved plans and relevant building regulations. Maintain a safe working environment and comply with occupational health and safety requirements.

8. Inspections

Arrange inspections at various stages of the construction process as required by your local council and the ACTPLA, such as foundation, framing, waterproofing, and final inspections.

9. Completion

Once construction is complete, engage a building certifier or surveyor to inspect the final works and issue a certificate of occupancy or compliance. This certification is essential for the occupation or use of the building.

Click On The Image Below To learn more about Owner Building in ACT

Click On The Image Below To Learn More About White Cards in ACT

Click On The Image Below To Learn More About ACT's Owner Builder license

Click on The Image Below to get an ACT Owner Builder Permit application form (online)

Click on The Image Below to get an ACT Owner Builder Permit application form

item.title: iBuild Shines in the Business Spotlight: A Journey of Growth and Innovation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.ns2:encoded:
We're thrilled to share that iBuild Building Solutions has been featured in a recent Business Spotlight article by the Eastern Innovation Business Centre, a non-profit organization dedicated to fostering innovation and scaling high-growth businesses. In the ever-evolving construction industry, iBuild has emerged as a pioneer, driving change through technology, innovation, and a strong commitment to sustainability. From its humble beginnings as a startup, iBuild has grown into a medium-sized enterprise, revolutionising the construction sector with its unique approach to kit homes and prefabricated buildings. Founded by CEO Jackson Yin and co-founder Michael Zeng, iBuild's journey started with determination and a garage in Mount Waverley. Today, they not only provide innovative housing solutions but also contribute to education and skills development in the community, offering scholarships and internships to university students. iBuild's dedication to the local community is further exemplified by their commitment to diversity and inclusion, creating job opportunities and prioritising hiring from culturally diverse backgrounds. Sustainability is at the core of iBuild's operations, as iBuild utilises eco-friendly materials, renewable energy systems, and green building principles to minimise their ecological footprint. The business growth has been fueled by a digital transformation journey, embracing advanced technology, including virtual reality and augmented reality, to provide customers with exceptional experiences. iBuild's commitment to excellence has earned them numerous awards, including the Australian Export & Investment Award, Northern Business Achievement Awards, and recognition as a digitally aware and community-oriented company in a comprehensive report by META, Thoughtlab, and HATCH. As the construction industry continues to evolve, iBuild remains at the forefront, driving positive change and setting new standards for excellence. The dedication to innovation and high-quality construction solutions positions iBuild for even greater growth in the future.

CLICK IMAGE BELOW TO LEARN MORE

item.title: Nurturing The Future Generation Of Aussie Tradies
item.dc:creator: iBuildComms
item.ns2:encoded:
HELPING FUTURE TRADIES TO GET THE INTERVIEW SKILLS THEY NEED TO SUCCEED

iBuild was thrilled to participate in the recent Speed X Interviews program, organised by Gateway LLENS, Victoria's leading education and business connector. This event brought together 35 businesses and nearly 100 students for an engaging and informative experience.

The Speed X Interviews program is dedicated to supporting Year 11 and 12 students who are pursuing apprenticeships, aiming to become Australia's future electricians, plumbers, and other skilled tradies. It provides them with a unique opportunity to connect with local employers, explore various career options, and develop practical interview skills in a real-world setting.

item.title: Herald Sun Highlights iBuild's Triumph at 2024 Telstra Best of Business Awards
item.dc:creator: iBuild
item.ns2:encoded:
iBuild as part of the 2024 Telstra Best of Business Awards: Victorian Outstanding Growth Award has made waves in the Herald Sun. Hearld Sun's Journalist Vanessa Croll writes that Telstra's annual awards celebrate Aussie businesses making a splash. With over 22,000 nominations, iBuild along with seven other small Victorian businesses won because they are leading the way when it comes to innovation and economic know-how. Amanda Hutton one of the group executives at Telstra in her interview with Croll praised iBuild and the other Victorian best of businesses award winners as the cream of the crop, inspiring the next generation of entrepreneurs with the diverse categories highlighting each business's achievements, showcasing their impact on helping Aussie economy thrive. Check out what set iBuild apart from the other 22,000 applicants by clicking on the link and reading the article below. The win not only helps us celebrate a decade of helping hundreds of Aussies build their own homes it also shines a light on how Aussie small business are helping keep the Australian dream alive.

item.title: The Guardian Spotlights iBuild's Award-Winning Growth
item.dc:creator: iBuild
item.ns2:encoded:
In a recent feature, The Guardian showcased the winners of Telstra's Best of Business Awards 2024, celebrating small businesses as vital contributors to the heartbeat of the Australian economy.

It was awesome to see iBuild recognised as one of Australia's outstanding growing businesses that as The Guardian says is helping to simplify construction for hundreds of Aussies so they can build their own dream homes.

This milestone reminds us that as we approach our 10th anniversary this year our goal is to keep growing so that we can not only help hundreds more Aussies fulfill the Australian dream but also help our customer build future homes in much stronger, faster, and smarter way than ever before.

item.title: The Star Weekly Highlights iBuild's Creation of Local Aussie Jobs
item.dc:creator: iBuildComms
item.ns2:encoded:
In a recent feature, iBuild's local paper, The Star Weekly, highlighted what it means for a local business like iBuild to win at the Telstra Best of Business Awards 2024. The focus was on how the outstanding growth of local small businesses contributes to the creation of more Aussie jobs. Star Weekly's writer Gerald Lynch indicates that without local small manufacturing businesses like iBuild operating and growing to boost the Australian job market, it would be nearly impossible for there to be local Aussie manufacturing jobs. This recognition of iBuild's growth and contribution to local jobs reminds us of the pride we take in being part of a journey that helps hundreds of people build homes that are distinctly Australian made.

item.title: iBuild Wins 2024 Telstra Best of Business Award for Outstanding Growth in Victoria
item.dc:creator: iBuild
item.ns2:encoded:
ibuild's golden start to 2024

We are thrilled to announce that iBuild has been honoured with the prestigious 2024 Telstra Best of Business Awards, emerging as the distinguished winner of Victorian Outstanding Growth Award! This remarkable achievement marks a significant milestone for iBuild, reaffirming our position as one of Australia's most exceptional businesses among the top 0.2%. At iBuild, we take immense pride in our exceptional design and manufacturing capabilities, which continue to provide stylish and affordable housing solutions to our valued customers. Driven by our commitment to excellence, iBuild operates on a steadfast ethos of delivering structures that are stronger, smarter, faster, and more affordable. This dedication has propelled us from local hero to competing and winning on the global stage. Jackson Yin, the Managing Director of iBuild, attributes our success to the unwavering dedication of our team to uphold the highest standards of quality. "Quality isn't merely a commitment; it's the cornerstone of iBuild Building Solutions. We are dedicated to crafting homes that not only meet but exceed expectations, ensuring that each residential customer finds a place they are proud to call home." Our impact extends far beyond Australian shores. In addition to serving clients in every state and territory within Australia, iBuild has successfully exported its products to countries across the South Pacific and West Africa. Furthermore, our commitment to excellence has been recognised through the attainment of Approved Supplier status for both the Victorian Government and the United Nations. As we celebrate this remarkable achievement, we extend our heartfelt gratitude to our dedicated team, loyal customers, and supportive partners for their invaluable contributions to our success. Together, we will continue to innovate and deliver exceptional housing solutions, making a positive impact on communities both locally and globally.

IBUILD AT THE TELSTRA BEST OF BUSINESS AWARDS GALA

We extend our heartfelt gratitude to everyone who has been a part of our incredible journey in making hundreds of homes across Australia.

You May Be Interested In
item.ns3:encoded: We are thrilled to announce that iBuild has been honoured with the prestigious 2024 Telstra Best of Business Awards, emerging as the distinguished winner of Victorian Outstanding Growth Award!

item.title: Metro Kit Homes - Avila MV
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth
item.ns2:encoded:
Our Kit Homes Avila MV is compliant with the Victorian Department of Planning and Resources SSD (Small Second Dwelling) definition. This means you could construct an Avila as a granny flat in your backyard while bypassing planning permits previously required by council. Avila is compliant with current Silver Livable Standards for accessibility as well.

This Avila MV is like our standard Avila, without our covered decking. This keeps our total covered area within 60 sqm, allowing for this permit exemption.

Note this is only for Melbourne Metropolitan areas, and you will have to confirm your site and project can proceed with this permit exemption. This exemption does not apply to building permits. For more information, please check out the Victorian Department of Planning and Resources here.

If you would like to explore other options with Victoria's planning permit exemptions in metro areas, please let our experienced sales member know.
